author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Markham Heid
title: Just How Healthy Is Salmon?
description: Experts explain why it’s such a nutritional powerhouse and if all varieties are created equal.
content: Salmon is good for you — that part we know.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: A Novel of the Spanish Conquest, Magic Mushrooms Included
description: Álvaro Enrigue’s “You Dreamed of Empires” is a hallucinatory tale of the conquistadors’ arrival at Moctezuma’s gates.
content: The Mexican writer Álvaro Enrigue’s new novel has a soft, nebulous title: “You Dreamed of Empires.” Its cover is forgettable, too. Like nearly every book on the New Fiction table, it is all wavy patterns and beach-towel colors. This generic look has come to promise a) bright settings and b) young characters out to conquer racial and sexual threats as they perceive them. This would be excellent were it not for, as often as not, c) writing in which one is instructed how to feel at almost every moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim and Kate Christobek
title: N.R.A. Leader Accused of Unchecked Spending as Corruption Trial Begins
description: The New York attorney general is seeking penalties against several current and former leaders of the embattled gun-rights group.
content: Just days after the resignation of its longtime leader, the National Rifle Association faced off in a Manhattan court on Monday in a long-awaited civil showdown with the New York attorney general’s office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: 20 Looks That Did the Most at the Golden Globes
description: On a night full of fashion, these outfits stood out.
content: This year’s revamped Golden Globe Awards brought several changes to the program. But it was business as usual on the red carpet, with hundreds of celebrities seemingly relishing the chance to give us something to ogle after last year’s strikes stopped many from posing for cameras at award shows and events.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: How an Obscure Song Became an a Cappella Sensation
description: Few people were aware of the 1994 single “Insomniac” by the rock duo Billy Pilgrim, and it quickly sank into obscurity. But a cappella groups can’t stop singing it. We set out to find an explanation.
content: In high school, I joined Rebel Yell, an a cappella group named after the Billy Idol song. I mostly beatboxed or sang background vocals. But one year, my chorus teacher gave me a lead vocal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colbi Edmonds
title: California’s Ban on Guns in Most Public Places Is Blocked Again
description: Just a week after the law was allowed to take effect, a federal appeals court reinstated a lower court’s block on the ban.
content: California is barred again from enforcing its ban on guns in most public places after a federal appeals court ruled on Saturday that a lower court’s block on the ban should stand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Nuwer
title: Africa’s Birds of Prey Are in Decline, a New Study Finds
description: Numbers have dropped, in some cases sharply, for nearly all of the 42 raptor species surveyed in sub-Saharan regions.
content: Silhouettes of patrolling raptors filled skies throughout Africa as recently as a few decades ago, but it’s much less common to spot those birds of prey today. Now, new research gives an indication of just how sharp the birds’ decline has been.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh and Liset Cruz
title: Pro-Palestinian Demonstrators Block N.Y. Bridge and Tunnel Traffic
description: Hundreds of demonstrators protesting Israel’s bombardment of Gaza blocked the Manhattan entrance to the Holland Tunnel and disrupted traffic on three major bridges.
content: Pro-Palestinian demonstrators on Monday blocked off entrances to the Holland Tunnel and the Brooklyn, Manhattan and Williamsburg Bridges, disrupting rush-hour traffic in Manhattan as they protested Israel’s bombardment of the Gaza Strip and called for a cease-fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: Two Capitol Riots. Two Very Different Results.
description: Why has Brazil united in rejecting last year’s insurrection, while the United States remains deeply divided over Jan. 6?
content: Monday marks one year since thousands of right-wing protesters draped in the colors of the Brazilian flag stormed into Brazil’s Congress, Supreme Court and presidential offices with a violent fury and the goal of overturning an election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: The Election No One Seems to Want Is Coming Right at Us
description: It’s 2024. Sorry.
content: Gail Collins: Hey, Bret, it really is 2024 now. Happy new year. And the race is on! Next week, the Iowa caucuses. After Iowa …
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: nondenominational
description: This word has appeared in 24 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word nondenominational has appeared in 24 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 21 in “At U.N., Narendra Modi Celebrates Yoga, and Joins In on a Pose” by Sarah Maslin Nir:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: A snowstorm in Iowa is hindering Republicans’ campaign plans.
description: In the last week before the Republican caucuses, the threat of heavy snow has forced Nikki Haley, Vivek Ramaswamy and Donald J. Trump to alter their schedules.
content: A storm that is forecast to dump close to a foot of snow in parts of Iowa on Monday and Tuesday is upending the campaigning plans of some candidates as they try to make the most of the last week before the Republican caucuses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: Claudine Gay Was Not Driven Out Because She Is Black
description: Opposing D.E.I. is not the same as racism.
content: Since Claudine Gay’s resignation as president of Harvard University on Tuesday, it has become an article of faith among some of her supporters and other observers that she was targeted, criticized and essentially driven from the job largely because of her race. The idea is that the people who questioned her abilities and academic integrity — be they Harvard donors who found fault with her leadership after Oct. 7 or conservative activists who led an inquiry into plagiarism in her scholarly work — were marked and even motivated by animus toward a Black woman attaining such a degree of power and influence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith and Andrew Das
title: Franz Beckenbauer, ‘Der Kaiser’ of World Soccer, Dies at 78
description: In West Germany, he revolutionized his central defense position and was one of only three people to win the World Cup as a player and a coach.
content: Franz Beckenbauer, a World Cup winner as a player and a coach who became the defining figure in German soccer for more than half a century, died on Sunday. He was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Rubin
title: An Innovative Vocalist Lost Her Speech, but She’s Still Performing
description: Linda Sharrock, an avant-garde jazz musician who became aphasic after a 2009 stroke, has returned to the stage and inspired new generations.
content: Last April, the Vienna-based avant-garde jazz vocalist Linda Sharrock gave her first New York performance in over 40 years: a sold-out concert at BAM’s Howard Gilman Opera House, as part of a series curated by Solange. Appearing between the poet Claudia Rankine and the saxophonist Archie Shepp, Sharrock guided eight musicians through a fully improvised set while she howled powerfully over the cacophonous squall of free jazz in a declamatory style that evoked the evening’s program title, “The Cry of My People.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Final Campaign Week in Iowa, and a Rare Moon Mission
description: Hear the news in five minutes.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley, Adam Entous and Edward Wong
title: Israel Says Its Military Is Starting to Shift to a More Targeted Gaza Campaign
description: Israeli officials privately say that they hope to complete the transition by the end of January, but that the timeline could change.
content: Israel said its military is starting to shift from a large-scale ground and air campaign in the Gaza Strip to a more targeted phase in its war against Hamas, and Israeli officials have privately told their American counterparts that they hoped the transition would be completed by the end of January, U.S. officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Jo Koy Responds to Golden Globes Criticism: ‘It’s a Tough Room’
description: In an interview on the ABC program “GMA3” the morning after the awards show, Koy said he would “be lying” if he said the criticism “doesn’t hurt.”
content: Hosting a Hollywood awards show can be a notoriously difficult job, with its audience of image-conscious A-list celebrities on the receiving end and a large television audience scrutinizing the material in real time. After Jo Koy’s performance as the host of this year’s Golden Globes drew criticism, he acknowledged Monday that it had been “a tough room.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Protesters Calling for Gaza Cease-Fire Interrupt Biden Speech
description: A group of protesters chanted “Cease-fire now.” Biden supporters countered with “Four more years.”
content: Protesters interrupted President Biden’s speech at a church in Charleston, S.C., on Monday, urging him to call for a cease-fire in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Golden Globes Draws 9.4 Million Viewers
description: The number of viewers was higher than last year, but still down significantly compared with prepandemic audience totals.
content: The Golden Globes averaged 9.4 million viewers on Sunday night, according to Nielsen, an increase over the 2023 ceremony ratings but still significantly lower than the audience totals of just a few years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi and Mark Walker
title: United and Alaska Airlines Find Loose Parts on Boeing 737 Max 9 Jets
description: The announcements added to safety concerns about the Max 9. United said loose bolts were found on panels like the one that blew out during an Alaska Airlines flight.
content: United Airlines and Alaska Airlines said on Monday that they had found loose parts on some of their Boeing 737 Max 9 jets after a fuselage panel blew out during an Alaska flight on Friday, adding to growing safety concerns about the Max 9.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Apparent ‘Swatting’ Incidents Target Judge and Prosecutor in Trump Election Case
description: The police were called to the homes of Judge Tanya S. Chutkan and the special counsel, Jack Smith, in separate incidents after false reports of shootings there.
content: Police officers and emergency personnel were sent on Sunday night to the Washington home of the federal judge overseeing former President Donald J. Trump’s election interference case in what appeared to be an incident of “swatting,” according to three people familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Kugel
title: Help! An Employee of Budget Kept My Phone and I Can Prove It.
description: After misplacing his iPhone while returning a rental car, a traveler tracked down the device and presented strong evidence to the agency that a worker took it — to no avail.
content: One day last July, I was dropping off a rental car at Budget’s location at Boston Logan International Airport when I misplaced my iPhone. As best as I can recall, I left it in the car while I went to throw away some trash, but neither my wife nor I nor the employee who was helping us could find it. After my flight home, I began tracking the phone using Apple’s Find My application, and after a trip through western Massachusetts and New Hampshire, the phone began traveling back and forth from an apartment building in Lynn, Mass., to the Budget office at Logan. I reported this to both Budget and the airport police, but the police told me that they could take action only if Budget gave them the name of any employees who lived at that address, and Budget would not help. I want Budget to return my phone or pay for a replacement. Can you help? John, Jacksonville, Fla.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: We Still Need to Talk About Government Debt
description: Last weekend’s deal is good news, but the basic problems remain.
content: I’m near-term slightly more optimistic but long-term pessimistic about the ability of the United States to deal with its budget problems. My uptick in optimism comes from a deal in Washington, while the pessimism comes from what I heard at an economics conference in San Antonio that I attended last weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Which TV Show or Movie Would You Want to Live?
description: Live interactive experiences inspired by popular shows like “Squid Game” and “Friends” are trending. Do they appeal to you?
content: Have you ever loved a TV show or movie so much that you wanted to walk through — or even exist within — its fictional world?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham and Charles Homans
title: Trump Is Connecting With a Different Type of Evangelical Voter
description: They are not just the churchgoing, conservative activists who once dominated the G.O.P.
content: Karen Johnson went to her Lutheran church so regularly as a child that she won a perfect attendance award. As an adult, she taught Sunday school. But these days, Ms. Johnson, a 67-year-old counter attendant at a slot-machine parlor, no longer goes to church.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Barton
title: Two Friends Reunite. One Has a Secret.
description: In “Goldenseal,” Maria Hummel takes readers into a hotel room, then unfurls her characters’ complicated history.
content: Maria Hummel’s new novel, “Goldenseal,” begins in 1990, when Edith Morgan returns to Los Angeles for the first time in 44 years with a secret for an old friend. Lacey Weber Crane, the pampered only child of German-speaking parents from Prague, is now a recluse in the glamorous hotel the women once owned. She’s so nervous at the thought of Edith’s arrival that she feels “her body betraying her, dampening her armpits, breathing out sour breath.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: Lily Gladstone Becomes First Indigenous Person to Win a Golden Globe for Best Actress
description: The star of “Killers of the Flower Moon” plays an Osage woman whose husband is part of a murderous conspiracy.
content: In a history-making triumph, Lily Gladstone has become the first Indigenous person to win a Golden Globe for best actress, said a spokesman for the organization that hands out the awards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Misleading SAT Debate
description: Higher education has a standardized-test problem.
content: Higher education has a standardized-test problem, and it’s not the problem that many people think.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colbi Edmonds and Rebecca Carballo
title: The Frightful Minutes Aboard Flight 1282
description: After a section of the Alaska Airlines flight blew out of the plane, passengers described a mix of horror, confusion and eerie calm.
content: It felt like an explosion. Then the plane rattled, the oxygen masks dropped, and the lights flickered. A white vapor whipped through the cabin. Some people yelled. Others were disoriented.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: China Says It Detained a Foreign Consultant for Spying for Britain
description: The Ministry of State Security says the consultant collected intelligence and found people on behalf of MI6, Britain’s spy agency.
content: China’s top intelligence agency said Monday that it had detained the head of an overseas consulting agency for working as a spy for the British government to collect Chinese state secrets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: ‘Oppenheimer’ Wins 5 Golden Globes and ‘Succession’ Wins 4
description: “The Holdovers,” “Poor Things” and “Barbie” all won multiple awards in the film categories, while the TV shows “Beef” and “The Bear” each won three.
content: The 81st Golden Globes kicked off Hollywood’s awards season on Sunday in a chaotic and sloppy manner, with the host, Jo Koy, delivering a train wreck of a monologue, winners alternately seeming to take the ceremony seriously and not at all, and prizes going to a wide array of films and television shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim
title: How Hillsdale Got Mixed Up in the 2020 Election Plot
description: The conservative college has become quietly involved in many political fights — including Trump’s attempt to overturn his defeat.
content: A few days before Thanksgiving 2020, a half-dozen or so people gathered at the home of a Michigan lawyer named Robert E. Norton II.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lucy Tompkins and Eli Durst
title: Can a Big Village Full of Tiny Homes Ease Homelessness in Austin?
description: One of the nation’s largest experiments in affordable housing to address chronic homelessness is taking shape outside the city limits.
content: On the outskirts of Austin, Texas, what began as a fringe experiment has quickly become central to the city’s efforts to reduce homelessness. To Justin Tyler Jr., it is home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Travelli
title: India and Maldives Trade Barbs After Modi’s Beach Visit
description: Some in the Maldives were critical of Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s trip to nearby Indian islands to promote tourism, seeing it as an attempt to draw visitors away from their nation.
content: It started with a postcard-perfect snapshot. An image of India’s prime minister, Narendra Modi, lounging in a chair on a secluded white-sand beach, provoked heated words from officials in the Maldives, a tiny archipelago nation in the Indian Ocean.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Chairman of Florida Republican Party Is Ousted Amid Scandal
description: Gov. Ron DeSantis and Senator Rick Scott had called for the resignation of the chairman, Christian Ziegler, who is being investigated for sexual assault.
content: The Republican Party of Florida ousted its chairman on Monday, more than a month after the police in Sarasota confirmed that he was under criminal investigation for sexual assault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Moskin
title: Why Is My Dessert on a Pedestal? 7 New Styles at the Restaurant Table.
description: The art of arranging food, known as plating, has entered a freewheeling new phase. Here are the latest fashions, fads and follies.
content: At the restaurant ILIS in Brooklyn, your smoked tomato and clam dashi arrives in a giant clamshell, sealed with beeswax and roped shut. At Naks in the East Village, bites of beef tartare on crisped beef fat are ferried to your table on a cow horn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israel Picks Holocaust Survivor Judge for Genocide Case, Surprising Some
description: Aharon Barak, a retired Israeli Supreme Court president, fought the government’s judicial overhaul plan. But it chose him for the panel hearing a case against it in a United Nations court.
content: As Israel prepares this week to face accusations at the International Court of Justice that it has committed genocide in the Gaza war, it has appointed one of the country’s most prominent jurists as the ad hoc judge to sit on the bench on its behalf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘The Curse’ and the Critics’ Choice Awards
description: The season ends for this Showtime series with Nathan Fielder and Emma Stone, while awards season begins.
content: With network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Jan. 8-14. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: JetBlue Chief Executive to Step Down
description: Robin Hayes described the decision to retire as “bittersweet,” and suggested that unspecified health concerns had driven it.
content: The chief executive of JetBlue Airways, Robin Hayes, said on Monday that he planned to step down after nine years in the role and while in the middle of trying to carry out a merger with Spirit Airlines that could reshape the industry, if it isn’t blocked in court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Will Reid, Carlos Prieto, Rob Szypko, Michael Simon Johnson, Marc Georges, Lisa Chow, Chelsea Daniel, Pat McCusker, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Corey Schreppel and Chris Wood
title: The Wild World of Money in College Football
description: How rich donors and loose rules are transforming college sports.
content: Tonight, millions of Americans are expected to tune in to watch one of the biggest sports events of the year, college football’s national championship game. On the field, the game will be determined by the skill of the players and coaches, but behind the scenes, secretive groups of donors are wielding enormous influence over what fans will see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: New President of Realtors Group Abruptly Resigns
description: Tracy Kasper, who took over as president of the National Association of Realtors after the sudden resignation of her predecessor, has quit after what the group described as a threat.
content: The president of the embattled National Association of Realtors has resigned, just four months into her tenure. Tracy Kasper is the second president to abruptly step down from N.A.R. — an organization that has seen its power and influence wane in recent months in the wake of losing a major antitrust lawsuit and amid allegations that leaders had ignored sexual harassment allegations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Nichol
title: My Sister Was Murdered 30 Years Ago. True Crime Repackages Our Pain as Entertainment.
description: I grew up watching the brief beauty of my sister’s life weaponized to usher in an era of mass incarceration and true crime obsession.
content: In the 1990s you would have been hard-pressed to find someone who didn’t know the name of my sister Polly Klaas. I was 6 years old when a stranger abducted 12-year-old Polly from our bedroom on the evening of Oct. 1, 1993. Her face quickly became a fixture on nightly news, her name featured prominently in headlines alongside fearmongering about crime rates. News crews broadcast from our living room and remained camped in front of our house during the two-month search before her body was found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: How to Define a Good Wine? It’s Complicated.
description: Yes, a wine ought to taste good. But there’s much more to consider, including farming, winemaking and intent.
content: What makes a wine “good”?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Taking a Cue From the Squirrels in My Birdhouse
description: To make it through the gathering disquiet, I will need embodied connection.
content: Just before 2023 gave way to 2024, my husband and I drove down a mountain, talking about how to manage election-year anxiety. Specifically, my election-year anxiety. We had just spent a few days in a cottage in the woods, and we were jazzed on silence and stillness and the obligation to do nothing but walk together among the trees. To listen to the wind in the trees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin and Michael Levenson
title: Man Who Attacked Las Vegas Judge Gets Up to 4 Years in Prison
description: The attack, which was caught on video, cut short a sentencing hearing for Deobra Redden on an earlier battery conviction. He now faces additional charges in the assault on the judge.
content: A judge who was attacked by a defendant in a Las Vegas courtroom last week sentenced the man on Monday to 19 to 48 months in prison on a previous battery charge, emphasizing that his actions last week did not affect her sentencing decision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $3 Million Homes in California
description: A Victorian rowhouse in San Francisco, a 1966 ranch house in Malibu and a three-bedroom home in Menlo Park.
content: This house is in Potrero Hill, about a 10-minute walk from Zuckerberg San Francisco General Hospital and Trauma Center. It is also within walking distance of a public library, public elementary and high schools, and Potrero Hill Recreation Center, which sits in a park with a baseball diamond, tennis courts and a playground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Prince’s ‘Purple Rain’ Is Being Developed as a Stage Musical
description: Branden Jacobs-Jenkins is lined up to write the book, and Lileana Blain-Cruz will direct.
content: “Purple Rain,” Prince’s breakout rise-of-a-rock-star film, is being adapted into a stage musical featuring some of the pop musician’s best-loved songs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
title: 4 Aides to Austin Waited 2 Days to Tell White House About His Hospitalization
description: The defense secretary remains in the hospital but is in “good condition” and conducting official business, the Pentagon spokesman said.
content: Four top aides to Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III were informed last Tuesday that he had been hospitalized a day earlier but did not notify the White House until two days later, the Pentagon said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stuart A. Thompson
title: Dark Corners of the Web Offer a Glimpse at A.I.’s Nefarious Future
description: In the hands of anonymous internet users, A.I. tools can create waves of harassing and racist material. It’s already happening on the anonymous message board 4chan.
content: When the Louisiana parole board met in October to discuss the potential release of a convicted murderer, it called on a doctor with years of experience in mental health to talk about the inmate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin P. Russell
title: Writing in an Endangered Language to Honor, and Challenge, Traditions
description: In “How to Be a Good Savage,” Mikeas Sánchez’ poems help preserve her language, Zoque, and allow it to commingle with English and Spanish, in an effort that is both global and deeply local.
content: Mikeas Sánchez writes poetry in Zoque, a language spoken by around 100,000 people. The variant she grew up with, called Copainalá, is considered endangered; some 15,000 people use it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: To Cut Back on Drinking, Try Damp January
description: Experts say that making an effort to drink less can benefit your health and help you build good habits around alcohol.
content: Raise a mock margarita or a phony Negroni — Dry January is once again in full swing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Is It Ever OK to Wear Matching Sweats?
description: A reader wonders whether the Y2K-era staple is cringey — or due for a comeback.
content: Karl Lagerfeld, the Chanel designer whose talent for dramatic pronouncements was equaled only by his talent for dreaming up extraordinary clothes, once declared sweatpants “a sign of defeat.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The On Politics Team
title: Send Us Your Questions About the 2024 U.S. Presidential Election
description: Got a query, or just curious about the election? The On Politics newsletter team can help: We’re answering reader questions.
content: If you’re wondering: What’s the difference between a caucus and a primary? How does the Electoral College work, again? Which important voting deadlines should be on my calendar?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Sack
title: Many Have Preached Politics From This Pulpit, but Biden Is the First President
description: Mr. Biden visited Emanuel A.M.E. Church after a racist massacre in 2015 to mourn with a shaken congregation. He returned Monday to warn of the political threats of hate-filled violence.
content: Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Charleston, S.C., the oldest A.M.E. church in the South, will forever be associated with former President Barack Obama because of his memorable — and melodic — eulogy for the nine victims of a racist massacre in its fellowship hall in June 2015.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Boeing Max 9 Jets Remain Grounded as Airlines Await Inspection Instructions
description: Two days after a chunk of the fuselage blew out of one of the planes, the F.A.A. and the aircraft maker are still negotiating what to tell the airlines to do.
content: A Boeing passenger jet model, the 737 Max 9, remained grounded in the United States on Sunday as airlines awaited instructions from the plane maker and the Federal Aviation Administration on how to inspect the planes and resume service, two days after a harrowing flight raised concerns about the jet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward and Adam Rasgon
title: Here’s What to Know About Hezbollah’s Radwan Force
description: The elite unit of the Lebanese armed group lost a commander in a strike on Monday.
content: Israel has long seen Hezbollah, with thousands of trained fighters and a deep arsenal of rockets and other weapons, as the most formidable foe on its borders. And Israeli officials say Hezbollah’s elite Radwan force, in particular, poses a major threat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Travis Diehl
title: Alexis Smith, Artist With Eclectic Eye on American Culture, Dies at 74
description: She used installations, assemblage and three-dimensional murals in her commentary on Hollywood, fame and more. “I’ve made stuff out of everything,” she said.
content: Alexis Smith, an artist who expressed a searing though affectionate vision of American culture in assemblages, installations and public art projects, died on Tuesday at her home in Venice, Calif. She was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Tuesday Briefing: Israel’s New Phase in Gaza
description: Also, a recap of the Golden Globes.
content: Israel has begun a new and less intense phase of its invasion of Gaza, its military said, after weeks of pressure to scale back its offensive. But its chief of staff said that the country was ready for “another war” against Hezbollah, which said a commander was killed in a strike in Lebanon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: France’s Prime Minister Resigns Ahead of Cabinet Reshuffle
description: Élisabeth Borne, only the second woman to occupy the position, stepped down as President Emmanuel Macron tries to inject fresh energy into his second term.
content: Prime Minister Élisabeth Borne of France resigned on Monday ahead of a widely expected cabinet reshuffle by President Emmanuel Macron, as he attempts to inject new energy into his presidency at the start of a year of major events in France, including European Parliamentary elections and the Summer Olympics in Paris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: Boeing’s Stock Drops as Investors Assess Fallout From 737 Max Incident
description: The aircraft maker and a key supplier of parts were punished in the markets after a chunk of a plane’s fuselage blew out on an Alaska Airlines flight.
content: Boeing’s share price fell sharply on Monday, in the first trading session after part of the fuselage of one of its 737 Max 9 jets blew out on an Alaska Airlines flight on Friday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: TikTok Quietly Curtails Data Tool Used by Critics
description: People and groups had harnessed the tool to scrutinize content on the site related to the Israel-Hamas war and other topics.
content: TikTok has quietly restricted one of its few tools to help measure the popularity of trends on the video app, after the tool’s results were used by researchers and lawmakers to scrutinize content on the site related to geopolitics and the Israel-Hamas war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Francis Urges Ban on Surrogacy, Calling It ‘Despicable’
description: The pope said that an unborn child must not be “turned into an object of trafficking,” expanding his condemnation of a practice already illegal in Italy and some other European countries.
content: Pope Francis on Monday called surrogate motherhood a “despicable” practice that should be universally banned for its “commercialization” of pregnancy, including the practice among wars, terrorism and other threats to peace and humanity in an annual speech to ambassadors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Emma Stone Wins Her Second Golden Globe, for ‘Poor Things’
description: The actress won for her performance as Bella, a Victorian-era woman who was brought back to life with the brain of a fetus.
content: Emma Stone won her second Golden Globe, for her performance in “Poor Things,” a comedy-drama riff on the Frankenstein legend. In the film, she plays Bella, a Victorian-era woman who was brought back to life with the brain of a fetus; her performance was widely praised by critics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: Boeing Max 9 Plane Had Been Barred From Long Flights Over Water
description: Alaska Airlines restricted the use of the plane, which lost part of its fuselage on Friday, because of a warning light that went off on previous flights, an official said.
content: The Alaska Airlines plane that lost a piece of its fuselage in midair on Friday was not being used in long flights over water because a pressurization warning light had gone off during three recent flights, the National Transportation Safety Board said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Why Iowa Turned So Red When Nearby States Went Blue
description: Over the past 15 years, the Upper Midwest has seen a remarkable state-by-state sorting of voters along partisan lines.
content: With the Iowa caucuses six days away, politicians will be crisscrossing the state, blowing through small-town Pizza Ranches, filling high school gyms, and flipping pancakes at church breakfasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: How the Met’s Prop-Shop Magic Makes Trucks Move Onstage
description: In the Metropolitan Opera’s production of “Carmen,” three pickup trucks and a tractor-trailer are crucial props.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll find out what drives the trucks on the stage in “Carmen” at the Metropolitan Opera. We’ll also get details on subway service on the 1, 2 and 3 lines after the derailment last week on the Upper West Side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Jo Koy Sticks With Standard Celebrity Teasing in Opening Monologue
description: The comic’s monologue struck a far less provocative tone than last year’s host, Jerrod Carmichael.
content: In his opening monologue, Jo Koy made a return to the Hollywood tradition of mild celebrity teasing from the awards show stage, staying away from any mention of the Golden Globes’ recent troubled history involving race and ethics.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Biden’s Harsh Attack on Trump in a Campaign Speech
description: Readers agree with the president that democracy is imperiled if his predecessor is elected. Also: The Japan plane crash; how the movie “Munich” resonates.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: As the College Sports Model Teeters, Michigan Tries to Keep a Balance
description: The national football championship on Monday between the Wolverines and Washington Huskies comes at a time of dramatic upheaval for a uniquely American enterprise.
content: Growing up in Hawaii, Roman Wilson didn’t realize how much money was in college football until his senior year in high school when he took a weeklong recruiting visit to the mainland. His first stops were Cal-Berkeley and U.C.L.A. “Very nice facilities,” he thought.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By D.W. Gibson
title: For a Brooklyn Family, the Infestation of Rodents Seems Endless
description: In Williamsburg, city housing authorities, the courts and, to a degree, even the landlord, are trying to help. But the mice and roaches keep coming.
content: Jackelyn Silva misses the days when she could store food in her cabinets without giving it a second thought. Or step away from the kitchen table for a moment without a worry.  “You can’t cook breakfast and leave it there,” she said, “because once you turn, you’ve got a roach on your food.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: Watch the Opening Scene of ‘Oppenheimer’
description: The writer and director Christopher Nolan narrates a sequence from his film, which won the Golden Globe for best drama.
content: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Which Trump Toady Would the MAGA King Pick as His No. 2?
description: The woman option is the one that most intrigues me.
content: With presidential primaries, it ain’t over till it’s over. Still, given the Republicans’ enduring devotion to their MAGA king, it’s best to mentally prepare oneself for the likelihood that the guy who has long been the prohibitive front-runner will, in fact, win the nomination. And a particularly juicy part of that preparation is obsessing over who Donald Trump will pick as his new pain sponge — erm, running mate — and what that choice could tell us about his strategy and state of mind this time around.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Mitch Landrieu, Biden’s Infrastructure Czar, Moves to Presidential Campaign
description: Mr. Landrieu championed public works projects across the country. He will now aim to rejuvenate Mr. Biden’s campaign in the face of voter frustration about the economy.
content: WILMINGTON, Del. — Mitch Landrieu, the coordinator of President Biden’s ambitious infrastructure program, is stepping down from his post to help lead the president’s re-election campaign, the White House said in a statement on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood
title: Pakistani Justices Reject Ban for Politicians With Past Convictions
description: The decision by the Supreme Court paves the way for a former prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, to run in parliamentary elections in February.
content: Pakistan’s Supreme Court on Monday overturned a law that barred politicians with past convictions from seeking political office, in a move that paves the way for former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif to run in parliamentary elections in February.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Investors Bail on Boeing Following Max 9 Grounding
description: The jet maker’s share price fell sharply in premarket trading on Monday after hundreds of flights were canceled and safety inspections resumed.
content: Investors are bailing on Boeing and one of its biggest suppliers this morning after a harrowing malfunction at 16,000 feet this weekend in which a door panel sheared off a new 737 Max 9 airliner in midflight.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Town Turned Marijuana Oasis Near Texas Rakes In the Green
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, January 8, 2023.
content: “I’d like to see a nice store, a pharmacy, a gas station that’s close to my home. Instead, all we see is cannabis.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Omar G. Encarnación
title: Spain Is Doing Something Brave
description: A new amnesty law could be a remedy for democratic coexistence.
content: Spain’s new amnesty law, on its way to the statute books after passing Congress in December, has ignited quite a ruckus. Tens of thousands of people have taken to the streets to protest the law — which provides a blanket pardon to hundreds of politicians, civil servants and ordinary citizens caught up in the illegal referendum on Catalan independence in October 2017 — and a majority of Spaniards oppose it. Many commentators and politicians, mainly on the right, have argued that the amnesty weakens the rule of law in Spain and even imperils the country’s democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Ali Wong Makes History as a Best Actress Winner
description: The “Beef” star took home a Golden Globe, as did Steven Yeun, who starred alongside her.
content: Ali Wong’s character in the Netflix comedy “Beef” faced plenty of challenges and frustrations, but the actress herself was nothing less than triumphant on Sunday night. Wong made history by becoming the first actress of Asian descent to win a Golden Globe for best actress in the limited series or TV movie category.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Tries to Rally Disaffected Black Voters in Fiery Condemnation of Trump
description: The president visited Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Charleston, S.C., the site of one of the most horrific hate crimes in recent years, to denounce racism and extremism.
content: President Biden sought to rally disaffected Black supporters on Monday with a fiery condemnation of former President Donald J. Trump, linking his predecessor’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election to the nation’s history of white supremacy in what he called “the old ghost in new garments.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: How to Fall in Love With Tofu
description: The tangy, spicy notes in this sweet chile grain bowl will delight both the tofu faithful and the merely tofu curious.
content: In my column this week I wrote about my quest to eat more plant-based meals, with the goal to become as fluent in tofu as I am in chicken thighs. Turns out, those proteins have a lot in common, including an affinity for pungent marinades and a tendency to become their tastiest selves when laid out on a sheet pan and blasted with high heat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: India’s Top Court Reverses Early Release of 11 Men Convicted of Gang Rape
description: The case of Bilkis Bano, who was three months pregnant when she was attacked, became a powerful symbol of communal bloodshed and of the widespread violence against women in the country.
content: India’s top court on Monday restored life sentences for 11 Hindu men convicted of the gang rape of a Muslim woman in a case that became a powerful symbol of the widespread violence against Indian women and of communal tensions often exacerbated by Indian politicians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: World War II-era Munitions Found Dumped Off Los Angeles Coast
description: Using a high-tech underwater camera, researchers identified anti-submarine explosives, smoke devices and boxes of munitions on the ocean floor.
content: When marine scientists sent an underwater camera down to the seafloor off the Southern California coast, they expected to find the remnants of barrels used to dump chemical waste decades ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Some California Farmers Pay for Groundwater. Is That Workable?
description: A conversation with Coral Davenport, a climate reporter, about a novel water payment system in the Pajaro Valley.
content: It’s Monday. Behind a program that charges farmers in the Pajaro Valley for groundwater. Plus, California and other states that rely on the dwindling Colorado River are racing to agree on consumption cuts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Taylor Swift’s ‘1989 (Taylor’s Version)’ Tops Chart Again
description: Swift holds at No. 1 as Christmas favorites vanish from Billboard’s top 10 albums. Morgan Wallen’s “One Thing at a Time” is at No. 2.
content: A week ago, holiday titles dominated Billboard’s album chart, occupying half the top 10. But now that streaming playlists are no longer overindexing on roasting chestnuts, things have gone back to normal. Which means, of course, that Taylor Swift is (still) on top.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: Robots Learn, Chatbots Visualize: How 2024 Will Be A.I.’s ‘Leap Forward’
description: A.I. is set to advance at a rapid rate, becoming more powerful and spreading into the physical world.
content: At an event in San Francisco in November, Sam Altman, the chief executive of the artificial intelligence company OpenAI, was asked what surprises the field would bring in 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: 2024 Golden Globes: Photos From the Red Carpet
description: All the best looks from the first major award show of the year.
content: Celebrities streamed onto the lush red carpet to pose in front of the floral backdrop for the Golden Globes on Sunday night as the awards ceremony made a return to television (it wasn’t broadcast in 2022, and was moved to a Tuesday evening last year).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Carter for The New York Times
title: What Winning a Golden Globe Looks Like
description: Lily Gladstone, Paul Giamatti, Billie Eilish and stars from “Succession,” “Beef” and “The Bear” are captured in their moments of glory.
content: The Los Angeles-based photographer Erik Carter was backstage at the Beverly Hilton Hotel on Sunday, where he photographed Golden Globes winners for The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Goodman
title: Best and Worst Moments From the 2024 Golden Globes
description: Lily Gladstone made history, Jo Koy did not. And dressing on a theme proved a hit. These were just some of the highs and lows.
content: The Golden Globes had a lot to prove Sunday night. It was the award show’s return to a primo broadcast time slot after a series of scandals over finances and lack of diversity upended what used to be known as the biggest party of the year in Hollywood. Now privately owned with a greatly expanded pool of voters, the Globes were making a bid for relevance. Did that bid succeed? Well, it helped that this was the first major televised ceremony since the writers’ and actors’ strikes brought Hollywood to a halt, and stars and studios looking to goose their Oscar chances turned out after some skipped last year’s event. Then again, this wasn’t the liveliest show. Here are the highs and lows as we saw them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Monday Briefing
description: A newly aggressive Iran.
content: Hamas’s Oct. 7 attacks in Israel and Israel’s bombardment of the Gaza Strip have emboldened a newly aggressive Iran. After launching scores of attacks across the region, Iranian proxy groups have come into direct conflict with U.S. forces twice in the past week, and Washington is openly threatening airstrikes if the violence does not abate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo and Judson Jones
title: U.S. Faces Week of Extreme Weather, Including Blizzards and Flooding
description: A series of powerful weather systems moving across the country will bring heavy snow to the Plains and up to four inches of rain to the Northeast, forecasters said.
content: A series of powerful major weather systems are moving across the United States this week, bringing “extremely dangerous” blizzard conditions to the center of the country, widespread damaging winds across the East, tornadic storms to the South and “significant” flooding to the Northeast, forecasters warn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall, Vladyslav Golovin and Mauricio Lima
title: Exhausted, on the Defensive and at ‘Hell’s Gate’ in Ukraine
description: The country’s forces along a broad stretch of the front say that, with Russia pushing forward, the war has never been so dangerous.
content: ZAPORIZHZHIA REGION, Ukraine — Under the cover of darkness, leaning forward under the weight of packs and rifles, a squad of soldiers walked along a muddy lane and slipped into a village house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez and Mary Beth Gahan
title: 21 Injured in Explosion at Fort Worth Hotel
description: The episode, which the authorities said was most likely caused by a gas leak, caused substantial damage to the Sandman Signature hotel in downtown Fort Worth.
content: At least 21 people were injured in an explosion that was most likely caused by a gas leak and substantially damaged a hotel in downtown Fort Worth on Monday afternoon, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: American Company’s Spacecraft Malfunctions on Its Way to the Moon
description: After a flawless launch to orbit, the privately built robotic Peregrine lander is unlikely to reach the lunar surface because of a failure in its propulsion system.
content: The first NASA-financed commercial mission to send a robotic spacecraft to the surface of the moon will most likely not be able to make it there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: ‘Welsh Tidy Mouse’ Tidies Tiny Welsh House
description: For months, a mysterious helper was cleaning up the work bench in Rodney Holbrook’s shed every night. He caught the visitor, tail and all, on video.
content: There was something strange going on in Rodney Holbrook’s backyard shed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: Blinken Says Saudi Arabia Remains Interested in Diplomatic Ties With Israel
description: The U.S. secretary of state, on a trip to the Middle East that included a meeting with the Saudi crown prince, said such a move would require an end to fighting in Gaza and steps toward a Palestinian state.
content: Antony J. Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, said on Monday that the leader of Saudi Arabia told him that establishing diplomatic recognition between the kingdom and Israel was still possible, but it required an end to the war in Gaza and practical steps toward a Palestinian state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Tenmile Distillery’s Single Malt Whisky Conjures the Hudson Valley and Scotland
description: Deluxe hot chocolate on the Upper East Side, a talk on national dishes and more food news.
content: American distillers have been turning their attention to single malts, defined in Scotland as whisky produced in one distillery from 100 percent malted barley. In the United States these rules are usually followed, but have yet to be mandated by government regulators; it should happen soon. In Wassaic, N.Y., in the Hudson Valley, John Dyson is betting on the appeal of American single malts at his Tenmile Distillery. A former state Commissioner of Agriculture and Tourism who owns Millbrook Vineyards & Winery nearby and Williams Selyem winery in California, Mr. Dyson hired Shane Fraser, a master distiller from Scotland, to run the distillery. Their Little Rest Whisky, with whisky spelled as it is in Scotland since the distillery produces the spirit as is done in Scotland, is the second edition, recently released after a very limited first run. It’s light bronze and scented of toast and honey, with notes of hazelnuts on the palate, and excellent to sip with or without ice. If terroir can shape a whiskey, this one evokes the gentle, welcoming Hudson Valley. The distillery also produces gin and vodka.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: The State of Play in Iowa: What to Know About the G.O.P. Presidential Caucuses
description: Donald Trump leads the polls by more than 30 points.
content: Voters in Iowa are about to cast their ballots, and we’re back, ready to guide you through what promises to be an election year like no other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Russia Pounds Several Ukrainian Regions With Missiles
description: The attack killed at least four people, wounded many others and caused heavy damage. It came as Moscow has intensified air assaults in recent days.
content: Russia launched a large-scale air attack against Ukraine on Monday, Ukrainian and Russian officials said, pounding several regions with missiles that killed at least four people, wounded more than 30 others and heavily damaged residential buildings and industrial sites.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Far Right Balks as Congress Begins Push to Enact Spending Deal
description: With little time to spare before a shutdown deadline, Speaker Mike Johnson will have to navigate the same political currents that did in his predecessor.
content: Congress on Monday began an uphill push to pass a new bipartisan spending agreement into law in time to avoid a partial government shutdown next week, with Speaker Mike Johnson encountering stiff resistance from his far-right flank to the deal he struck with Democrats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: ​This Year, DeSantis Won’t Loom as Large Over Florida Legislative Session
description: With Gov. Ron DeSantis focused on the presidential primaries, the session that starts next week could be unusually low key.
content: When the Florida Legislature begins its annual session on Tuesday, Gov. Ron DeSantis will be on hand — fleetingly. After giving his State of the State address, he will leave for Iowa, where he has a packed campaign schedule ahead of the Republican presidential caucuses on Jan. 15. Few in Tallahassee expect to see much of him in the months that follow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katia Riddle and Michael Levenson
title: Science Teacher Finds Missing Piece of Boeing Jet’s Fuselage in His Yard
description: Bob Sauer said that his 50-foot cedar trees had acted on the same scientific principle as an airbag, disrupting the door plug’s fall in an act known in physics as impulse.
content: Bob Sauer went into his backyard in suburban Portland, Ore., on Sunday night, flashlight in hand, to check if any pieces of the Alaska Airlines plane that had lost a part of its fuselage in midair had landed nearby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: Trump’s Lawyers Say He Should Be Immune From Prosecution in Georgia Case
description: The motion echoes an argument that former President Donald J. Trump is making in a separate federal criminal case against him.
content: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump in the election interference case in Georgia asked on Monday to have the criminal charges against him there dismissed based in part on an argument that Mr. Trump is also making in the federal criminal case against him: that presidents should enjoy sweeping immunity from criminal prosecution for “official acts” taken while in office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski and Christopher Kuo
title: ‘The Bear’ Wins Best Comedy at the Golden Globes
description: Its stars, Jeremy White and Ayo Edebiri, also won for their acting roles.
content: Globe voters said “Yes, chef,” to “The Bear,” which beat out “Ted Lasso” and “Abbott Elementary” to win best comedy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: Hochul to Propose A.I. Research Center Using $275 Million in State Funds
description: The “Empire A.I.” project would be a public-private partnership aimed at making New York a key player in artificial intelligence research.
content: In her third State of the State address, Gov. Kathy Hochul will propose a first-of-its-kind statewide consortium that would bring together public and private resources to put New York at the forefront of the artificial intelligence landscape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Impeachment and Border Talks Put G.O.P. at Odds Over Mayorkas
description: House Republicans are pressing to impeach the homeland security secretary just as Senate Republicans look to him to help cut a border security deal.
content: This week in the Republican-led House, G.O.P. representatives plan to kick off their formal effort to impeach Alejandro N. Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary who has been one of their favorite punching bags.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Vulcan Rocket Aces Its First Launch
description: Despite problems with one of its payloads, the new launcher’s flight was flawless, showing the potential of several vehicles that could chip away at SpaceX’s dominance.
content: A brand-new rocket lifted off early Monday morning from Cape Canaveral, Fla., sending multiple payloads on journeys into space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Jonathan Majors Says He Was ‘Shocked’ by Assault Conviction
description: Mr. Majors spoke on ABC’s “Good Morning America,” his first interview since being convicted of misdemeanor assault and harassment for attacking his girlfriend in a car.
content: Jonathan Majors, an ascending Hollywood star whose career was upended when he was found guilty last month of assault and harassment for attacking his girlfriend, said in an interview broadcast on Monday that he was “absolutely shocked” by the verdict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: Wealthy Donors Pull Back From New York City’s Escalating Problems
description: Philanthropists worry that the city’s complex tangle of crises — migrants, homelessness, housing, the cost of living — cannot be easily fixed.
content: At first glance, this might seem like just the right moment for New York City’s deep-pocketed philanthropists to flex some muscle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Binyamin Appelbaum
title: The Seeds Joe Biden Has Planted
description: President Biden has reinvigorated the government’s role as the nation’s most important investor.
content: There is a famous story by the French writer Jean Giono about a man who plants trees in a barren valley. “For three years he had been planting trees in this wilderness. He had planted one hundred thousand. Of the hundred thousand, twenty thousand had sprouted. Of the twenty thousand he still expected to lose about half, to rodents or to the unpredictable designs of Providence. There remained ten thousand oak trees to grow where nothing had grown before.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle
title: Supreme Court Appears Split Over Notice Requirements for Immigration Court
description: Although the legal question was narrow, the argument reflected broader debates about the immigration system.
content: The Supreme Court appeared divided on Monday over what counted as proper notice for the government to give to people facing deportation hearings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Cumming-Bruce
title: An Enforcer for a Strongman President Goes on Trial in Milestone Swiss Case
description: Ousman Sonko served the authoritarian president of Gambia for years, seeking asylum in Switzerland after losing his job. Now he faces charges of crimes against humanity.
content: For roughly 16 years Ousman Sonko wielded sweeping power in Gambia’s security apparatus, crushing opposition to the West African country’s authoritarian president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Israel Said It Had Begun a Less Intense Phase of the War
description: Also, the investigation into Boeing planes. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: Israel announced today that its military had begun a new and less intense phase of its war against Hamas, after weeks of pressure to curtail its large-scale ground and air campaign. Israeli officials privately told their American counterparts they hoped the transition would be completed by the end of the month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: An Antique Dress Held a Secret: A Coded Message From 1888
description: For nearly a decade, sleuths had tried to decode a cryptic note discovered in the silk bustle dress. An analyst finally cracked the case.
content: Sara Rivers Cofield was on her usual search for interesting period clothing about a decade ago when she noticed what appeared to be a “textbook” silk bustle dress from the 1800s at an antique mall in Maine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Wegman
title: What if Joe Biden Is Actually Right About 2024?
description: The president performed a public service by forthrightly stating what could happen to the country and its democracy if Trump wins again.
content: “What a sick … My God.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lazaro Gamio and Karen Yourish
title: Trump’s Pattern of Pressure to Overturn the 2020 Election
description: Donald J. Trump pressured state and federal government officials to overturn results of the 2020 election in more than 30 phone calls or meetings, according to The Times’s analysis of the indictments related to those efforts.
content: Donald J. Trump pressured state and federal government officials to overturn results of the 2020 election in more than 30 phone calls or meetings, according to The Times’s analysis of the indictments related to those efforts.
source.name: The New York Times

title: built for iframe
description: an iframe
content: an iframe
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: How Well Do You Know Paris and Its Literary Landmarks?
description: This quick quiz tests your general knowledge of the great European city — and suggests five Paris-based novels for your reading list.
content: This quick quiz tests your general knowledge of the great European city — and suggests five Paris-based novels for your reading list.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Heavy Snow Falls in Northeast
description: In parts of New England and New York, residents and road crews removed snow as the first major snowstorm of the winter season hit the region.
content: In parts of New England and New York, residents and road crews removed snow as the first major snowstorm of the winter season hit the region.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Video Captures Mouse Organizing Shed
description: Rodney Holbrook, a wildlife photographer in Wales, caught a mouse on camera decluttering his backyard shed.
content: Rodney Holbrook, a wildlife photographer in Wales, caught a mouse on camera decluttering his backyard shed.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Video Shows Aftermath of Strike in Southern Lebanon
description: A video circulating on social media on Monday showed the scene of a strike in Khirbet Selm, a village in southern Lebanon.
content: A video circulating on social media on Monday showed the scene of a strike in Khirbet Selm, a village in southern Lebanon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Hotel in Downtown Fort Worth Damaged by Apparent Explosion
description: Videos shared with The New York Times show debris strewn across the street outside the Sandman Signature hotel in Fort Worth.
content: Videos shared with The New York Times show debris strewn across the street outside the Sandman Signature hotel in Fort Worth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: ‘Oppenheimer’ | Anatomy of a Scene
description: The writer and director Christopher Nolan narrates the opening sequence from the film.
content: The writer and director Christopher Nolan narrates the opening sequence from the film.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and The Associated Press
title: Ukrainian Residential Buildings Destroyed by Russian Air Assault
description: Some civilians sheltered in subway stations as Russia launched a widespread missile attack on regions across Ukraine.
content: Some civilians sheltered in subway stations as Russia launched a widespread missile attack on regions across Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By United Launch Alliance and Reuters
title: Vulcan Rocket Lifts Off for the Moon
description: The rocket launched from Cape Canaveral, Fla., early Monday morning, sending a robotic spacecraft toward the surface of the moon.
content: The rocket launched from Cape Canaveral, Fla., early Monday morning, sending a robotic spacecraft toward the surface of the moon.
source.name: The New York Times
